sentences.sentence: Digory now saw that where four trees grew close together their branches had all been laced( 缠绕 ) together or tied together with switches( 细枝条 ) so as to make a sort of cage.
The two Elephants with their trunks and a few dwarfs( 矮人 ) with their little axes( 斧头 ) soon got it all undone( 解开 ).
There were three things inside.
One was a young tree that seemed to be made of gold;
the second was a young tree that seemed to be made of silver;
but the third was a miserable( 可怜的 ) object in muddy( 尽是泥的 ) clothes, sitting hunched up( 缩成一团的 ) between them.
“Gosh( 天哪 )!” whispered Digory. “Uncle Andrew!”
To explain all this we must go back a bit.
The Beasts, you remember, had tried planting and watering him.
When the watering brought him to his senses,

he found himself soaking wet( 湿透的 ), buried up to his thighs( 大腿 ) in earth (which was quickly turning into mud( 泥浆 )) and surrounded( 包围 ) by more wild animals than he had ever dreamed of in his life before.
It is perhaps not surprising that he began to scream and howl( 嚎哭 ).
This was in a way a good thing, for it at last persuaded everyone (even the Warthog( 疣猪 )) that he was alive.
So they dug him up again (his trousers were in a really shocking state by now).
As soon as his legs were free he tried to bolt( 逃跑 ),
but one swift( 敏捷的 ) curl( 卷曲 ) of the Elephant’s trunk round his waist soon put an end to that.
Everyone now thought he must be safely kept somewhere till Aslan had time to come and see him and say what should be done about him.
So they made a sort of cage or coop( 栏舍 ) all round him.
They then offered him everything they could think of to eat.
The Donkey( 驴子 ) collected great piles of thistles( 蓟 ) and threw them in, but Uncle Andrew didn’t seem to care about them.
The Squirrels bombarded him with( 投掷 ) volleys( 连发 ) of nuts,
but he only covered his head with his hands and tried to keep out of the way.
Several birds flew to and fro( 来回地 ) diligently( 勤奋地 ) dropping worms on him.
The Bear was especially kind.
During the afternoon he found a wild bees’ nest and instead of eating it himself (which he would very much like to have done) this worthy creature brought it back to Uncle Andrew.
But this was in fact the worst failure of all.
The Bear lobbed( 抛 ) the whole sticky( 黏的 ) mass over the top of the enclosure( 笼子 ) and unfortunately it hit Uncle Andrew slap( 拍打 ) in the face (not all the bees were dead).
The Bear, who would not at all have minded being hit in the face by a honeycomb( 蜂巢 ) himself,
could not understand why Uncle Andrew staggered( 踉跄 ) back, slipped( 滑倒 ), and sat down. And it was sheer( 十足的 ) bad luck that he sat down on the pile of thistles( 蓟 ).
“And anyway,” as the Warthog( 疣猪 ) said, “quite a lot of honey has got into the creature’s mouth and that’s bound to have done it some good.”
They were really getting quite fond of their strange pet and hoped that Aslan would allow them to keep it.
The cleverer ones were quite sure by now that at least some of the noises which came out of his mouth had a meaning.
They christened( 给…命名 ) him Brandy( 白兰地 ) because he made that noise so often.
In the end, however, they had to leave him there for the night.
Aslan was busy all that day instructing the new King and Queen and doing other important things, and could not attend to( 处理 ) “poor old Brandy( 白兰地 ).”
What with the nuts, pears, apples, and bananas that had been thrown in to him, he did fairly well for supper;
but it wouldn’t be true to say that he passed an agreeable night.
“Bring out that creature,” said Aslan. One of the Elephants lifted Uncle Andrew in its trunk and laid him at the Lion’s feet. He was too frightened to move.
“Please, Aslan,” said Polly, “could you say something to—to unfrighten( 使不害怕 ) him? And then could you say something to prevent him from ever coming back here again?”
“Do you think he wants to?” said Aslan.
“Well, Aslan,” said Polly, “he might send someone else. He’s so excited about the bar off the lamp-post growing into a lamp-post tree and he thinks—”
“He thinks great folly( 愚蠢 ), child,” said Aslan.
“This world is bursting with life for these few days because the song with which I called it into life still hangs in the air and rumbles( 发出低沉连续的响声 )in the ground.
It will not be so for long.
But I cannot tell that to this old sinner( 恶棍 ), and I cannot comfort him either;
he has made himself unable to hear my voice.
If I spoke to him, he would hear only growlings( 怒吼 ) and roarings( 咆哮 ).
Oh Adam’s sons, how cleverly you defend yourselves against all that might do you good!
But I will give him the only gift he is still able to receive.”
He bowed his great head rather sadly, and breathed into the Magician’s terrified( 惊恐的 ) face.
“Sleep,” he said. “Sleep and be separated for some few hours from all the torments( 痛苦 ) you have devised( 设计 ) for yourself.”
Uncle Andrew immediately rolled over( 倒在地上 ) with closed eyes and began breathing peacefully.
“Carry him aside and lay him down,” said Aslan. “Now, dwarfs( 矮人 )! Show your smith-craft( 铁匠手艺 ). Let me see you make two crowns( 皇冠 ) for your King and Queen.”
More dwarfs( 矮人 ) than you could dream of rushed forward to the Golden Tree.
They had all its leaves stripped off( 摘下 ), and some of its branches torn off( 拽下 ) too, before you could say Jack Robinson.
And now the children could see that it did not merely look golden but was of real, soft gold.
It had of course sprung up from the half-sovereigns( 半金镑，货币单位 ) which had fallen out of Uncle Andrew’s pocket when he was turned upside down;
just as the silver had grown up from the half-crowns( 半克朗，货币单位 ).
From nowhere, as it seemed, piles of dry brushwood( 断树枝 ) for fuel, a little anvil( 铁砧 ), hammers, tongs( 钳子 ), and bellows( 风箱 ) were produced.
Next moment (how those dwarfs( 矮人 ) loved their work!) the fire was blazing( 熊熊燃烧 ), the bellows( 风箱 ) were roaring( 呼呼作响 ), the gold was melting( 熔化 ), the hammers were clinking.
Two Moles( 鼹鼠 ), whom Aslan had set to dig (which was what they liked best) earlier in the day, poured out( 倒出 ) a pile of precious( 珍贵的 ) stones at the dwarfs( 矮人 )’ feet.
Under the clever fingers of the little smiths( 铁匠 ) two crowns( 皇冠 ) took shape—not ugly, heavy things like modern European crowns( 皇冠 ),
but light, delicate( 精致的 ), beautifully shaped( 造型优美的 ) circles that you could really wear and look nicer by wearing.
The King’s was set with rubies( 红宝石 ) and the Queen’s with emeralds( 绿宝石 ).
When the crowns( 皇冠 ) had been cooled in the river Aslan made Frank and Helen kneel( 跪下 ) before him and he placed the crowns( 皇冠 ) on their heads.
Then he said, “Rise up King and Queen of Narnia, father and mother of many kings that shall be in Narnia and the Isles( 岛屿 ) and Archenland.
Be just and merciful( 仁慈的 ) and brave. The blessing is upon you.”
Then everyone cheered or bayed or neighed( 嘶鸣 ) or trumpeted( 吼叫 ) or clapped its wings and the royal pair stood looking solemn( 庄重的 ) and a little shy,
but all the nobler for their shyness.
And while Digory was still cheering he heard the deep voice of Aslan beside him, saying:
“Look!”
Everyone in that crowd turned its head, and then everyone drew a long breath of wonder and delight.
A little way off, towering over( 高于 ) their heads, they saw a tree which had certainly not been there before.
It must have grown up silently, yet swiftly( 迅速地 ) as a flag rises when you pull it up on a flagstaff( 旗杆 ),
while they were all busied about the coronation( 加冕仪式 ).
Its spreading branches seemed to cast a light rather than a shade, and silver apples peeped( 慢慢露出 ) out like stars from under every leaf.
But it was the smell which came from it, even more than the sight, that had made everyone draw in their breath.
For a moment one could hardly think about anything else.

article_info.previous: 经过内心的挣扎，Digory没有听信女巫的话，而是选择信守承诺，带着银苹果回到了纳尼亚。Digory亲手种下了苹果，苹果将成为纳尼亚的保护树。

article_info.share_words: More Dwarfs than you could dream of rushed forward to the Golden Tree. They had all its leaves stripped of, and some of its branches torn off too, before you could say Jack Robinson.

question.cn: 两棵树是由什么制成的？
question.en: What were two trees made of?

options.cn: 两棵树都是由金子制成的。
options.en: They were both made of gold.

options.cn: 两棵树都是由银子制成的。
options.en: They were both made of silver.

options.cn: 一棵树是由金子制成的，一棵树是由银子制成的。
options.en: One was made of gold, and the other silver.

analysis: 文中提到：“One is a young tree that seemed to be made of gold; the second was a young tree that seemed to be made of silver. . . And now the children could see that it did not merely look golden but was of real, soft gold. . . just as the silver had grown up from the half-crowns.”由此可知，一棵是金币长出来的金树，一棵是银币长出来的银树，因此选C。

question.cn: 谁为国王和王后制作了皇冠？
question.en: Who made two crowns for the King and Queen?

analysis: 文中提到：“Now, dwarfs! Show your smith-craft. Let me see you make two crowns for your King and Queen. . . Under the clever fingers of the little smiths two crowns took shape. . . ”由此可知，是矮人负责为国王和王后制作皇冠，因此选C。

question.cn: 与现代皇冠相比，小矮人制作的皇冠怎么样？
question.en: How were the crowns made by the dwarfs compared with modern European crowns?

options.cn: 小矮人制作的皇冠更轻更精致。
options.en: The crowns made by the dwarfs were lighter and more delicate.

options.cn: 小矮人制作的皇冠更重但更精致。
options.en: The crowns made by the dwarfs were heavier but more delicate.

options.cn: 小矮人制作的皇冠更轻却不那么精致。
options.en: The crowns made by the dwarfs were lighter but less delicate.

analysis: 文中提到：“Under the clever fingers of the little smiths two crowns took shape-not ugly, heavy things like modern European crowns, but light, delicate, beautifully shaped circles that you could really wear and look nicer by wearing.”由此可知，矮人们制作的皇冠，比起现在欧洲的皇冠更轻，更精致，更漂亮，因此选A。

question.cn: 两个皇冠上镶嵌着什么？
question.en: What were two crowns set with?

options.cn: 两个皇冠都镶嵌着红宝石。
options.en: They were both set with rubies.

options.cn: 两个皇冠都镶嵌着绿宝石。
options.en: They were both set with emeralds.

options.cn: 国王的皇冠镶嵌着红宝石，王后的皇冠镶嵌着绿宝石。
options.en: The King’s was set with rubies, and the Queen's was set with emeralds.

analysis: 文中提到：“The King’s was set with rubies and the Queen’s with emeralds.”由此可知，国王的皇冠上镶嵌得是红宝石，王后的皇冠上是绿宝石。两个人的皇冠镶嵌的是不一样的。因此选C。

question.cn: 谁把皇冠放在国王和王后的头上？
question.en: Who put the crowns on the King’s and Queen’s heads?

analysis: 文中提到：“When the crowns had been cooled down in the river Aslan made Frank and Helen kneel before him and he placed the crowns on their heads.”由此可知，是Aslan为二人加冕，把皇冠戴在他们的头上，因此选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第42天
